entries.meaning: Sideways; with the side turned to the direction of some object.
(nautical) One side of a ship above the water line; all the guns on one side of a warship; their simultaneous firing.
(by extension) A forceful attack, be it written or spoken.
examples: Although slaveholders managed - through a combination of political compromise and ideological broadside - to contain the threat of a major anti-slavery compaign by fellow Southerners, planters could never be totally sure of non-slaveholders' loyalty to the social order.

entries.meaning: A large sheet of paper, printed on one side and folded.
The printed lyrics of a folk song or ballad; a broadsheet.

verbs.description: broadside (third-person singular simple present broadsides, present participle broadsiding, simple past and past participle broadsided)
